 2. We also note that there might be missing values, but in the provided data there are 96 consecutive points (4 days * 24 hours = 96) so no missing values in the input.
 3. We will use a time series model that can handle seasonality. Given the hourly data and the seasonality, we can use a seasonal autoregressive integrated moving average (SARIMA) model or exponential smoothing (like Holt-Winters). However, since we are only given 96 points, we need a model that can work with limited data.

 Given the constraints, we choose to use the Seasonal Naive method as a baseline because:
   - It is simple and often works well for seasonal data.
   - The data has a strong daily pattern (seasonal period of 24).

 The Seasonal Naive method uses the value from the same time in the previous season (i.e., same hour of the previous day) as the forecast.
